Name: Economics 1
Description:
To provide an overall understanding of the economic environment in which we live from both a micro
and macro perspective.

Name: Economics 1
Description:
To provide an overall understanding of the economic environment in which we live from both a micro
and macro perspective.

Name: Process Design Principles 2: Safety & Loss Prevention
Business Computer Applications 1
Description:
The purpose of this subject is to provide students with the knowledge, skills, and attributes for 
Business Computer Applications integrated and supported by other subjects, that includes in 
part: 
• Economics: Elasticity/Inelasticity of Demand and Supply (graphs and charts) 
• Financial Accounting: Budgets, Income Statements 
• Statistics for Accountants: mean, median, mode, probability, amortizations. 
• Communication: Social Media ethics and etiquette are integrated into this subject.

To empower students with knowledge and understanding of mathematical theory and principles of how to 
transform a real-world problem into a mathematical model through assumptions. On completion of the course 
the students should be able to solve a first order linear (or non-linear) differential equations, should be able to 
solve a second order linear differential equation by means of D-operator and Laplace transform. Furthermore, 
the students should be able to transform a time domain functions (or signal) to a frequency domain function 
(or signal) by mean of Fourier transform and Laplace transform. 
Students will have the ability to grasp basic to advanced difficult concepts in core electrical engineering subjects, 
and students will learn all about extensive use of Laplace and Fourier transforms equations which is related to 
linear algebra in circuit theory and signal processing
Name: Engineering Mathematics 2
Introduction to Chemical Reaction Engineering I

Description:
Introduction to the structure and function of organisms found in the marine 
environment. These will include Viruses, Bacteria, Archea, Protista, Porifera, 
Cnidaria, Platyhelminthes, Nematoda, Rotifera, Annelida, Arthropoda, Mollusca, 
and Echinodermata. Other invertebrate groups (including terrestrial) may be 
covered to provide students with context. 
The evolutionary links and relationships among various groups and their traits will 
be discussed. 
The module will also be practically based in the laboratory
Name: Marine Biology 2

Description:
This subject provides an essential foundation for third year Bachelor of Engineering Technology subjects, 
Communication Systems 3 and Control Systems 3 but is also a good foundation for the application of 
mathematical analysis in electrical and computer engineering in general. 
You will be expected to work together with other members of the class as well as people from Mathematical 
Sciences, such as Mathematics lecturers or tutors, to find and discuss your solutions to broadly-defined tutorial 
problems and practical assignments that have been prescribed for this subject. Your broadly-defined signal 
processing problem solutions, and discussions regarding them, constitute an important learning 
objective and development for Graduate 8: Individual, Team and Multidisciplinary Learning, as defined in 
the ECSA standard document for this qualification type.
Name: Signal Processing 2

Description:
Understanding the earth and its environments: An ocean world; history of marine 
science; the timeline of life on earth; earth structure and plate tectonics; the origin 
and movement of water on earth between the land, ocean and atmosphere; tidal 
forces; continental margins and ocean basins; basic concepts of natural 
hydrological systems (rivers, lakes, estuaries, ice and groundwater); nutrient 
cycling; basic seamanship.
Name: Marine Science
Management & Environmental Law for Chem Engineers
Computer Skills 1
Description:
Introduction to computers, computer utilisation (word-processing skills,
spreadsheet skills, presentation software), data management

Name: Biostatistics
Description:
The subject Biostatistics will provide learning opportunities to ensure that students 
are familiar with, and competent in, the scientific method, survey and sample 
design, graphical representation and basic statistics related to various fields of 
Marine Science. Students should be able to understand the most basic statistical 
tests and be able to interpret statistical results. The students will also attain 
sufficient background knowledge to explore and apply numeracy and statistics that 
may be necessary and appropriate for other subjects in the diploma.

Name: Ecology 1
Description:
TIntroduction to ecology, components of an ecosystem, energy in the ecosystem,
ecological interactions, productivity in the ecosystem, population dynamics

Name: Ecology 2
Description:
Ecology 2 introduces students to aquatic ecosystems from freshwater to estuaries
and coastal ecosystems.

Name: Marine Biology 1
Description:
Equip students with the knowledge and skills to be able to understand cellular 
biology, physiology and structure. Furthermore, students will be able to understand 
diversity in relation to the marine environment and the evolution of the organisms 
in the five kingdoms.

Name: Coastal Management 1
Description:
Coastal management 1 examines the coastal and marine environment and its 
management of human use and the influence on this unique environment. It also 
introduces the climate change phenomenon, its impacts on the marine and coastal 
environments.

Name: Coastal Management 2
Description:
Coastal management 2 introduces the concept of environmental impact 
assessment (EIA) in environmental management. It presents the legislative 
framework for EIA, including the underlying principles that support sustainable 
development. It outlines the import of EIA in the decision-making process by the 
authorities. It also provides knowledge on the development of the EIA report from 
inception, including screening, scoping, and the environmental management plans 
(for post-authorisation monitoring of the environment), to submission of the EIA 
report to the authorities for decision-making.

Name: Computer Skills 2
Description:
Processing, analysis and modelling of data, manipulating data sets, interpretation
of data, mapping and other applicable software, MATLAB

Name: Marine Aquaculture 1
Description:
An introduction to marine aquaculture operations both globally and in South Africa 
and detail on the most common species, including an understanding of the 
anatomy and lifecycles of the species that are being farmed, and the common types 
of systems in use. Introducing scientific and management factors and issues 
affecting aquaculture operations, including biological, physiochemical factors. Also, 
an introduction to the underlying principles, regulatory and economic issues related 
to the aquaculture field of operations.

Name: Marine Law 1
Description:
Marine Law 1 introduces the origins of common law as they relate to the 
environment. It examines the fundamental legal principles which form the basis for 
the interpretation of the legislation. It also introduces branches of law, with a focus 
on public law, e.g., Administrative, Constitutional and Criminal law. Specific 
legislation, e.g., the National Environmental Management Act, NEM: Integrated 
Coastal Management Act, etc., which is relevant to the management of various 
aspects of the coastal and marine environment and related activities are also 
explored.

Name: Marine Pollution 1
Description:
Introduction to marine pollution, introduction to ecotoxicology, introduction to
research methodology and statistics.

Name: Marine Resource Management 1
Description:
Introduction to fisheries management, fishing techniques, management of South 
African marine resources, regulation of fishing activities, Monitoring, Control and 
Surveillance

Name: Marine Science 2
Description:
Time and space scales of physical oceanographic processes, ocean circulation, 
wave characterization and impacts on the coast, sound in the ocean, water 
masses of the world’s oceans, oceanographic datasets and their sources.

Name: Marine Technology
Description:
Time and space scales of oceanographic processes, characteristics of ocean 
datasets, data collection and processing, oceanographic equipment and 
instrumentation, oceanographic software, hydrographic, topographic and 
bathymetric mapping, fishing equipment technology, remote sensing.

Name: Business Principles
Description:
Business Principles defines the different fields of business management and 
introduces the requirements for starting a small business. It focuses on business 
administration, including personnel supervision, enterprise planning and 
entrepreneurship. It considers start-up, small business operations and problems. It 
investigates business law and regulations and introduces e-commerce and home 
business operations. It investigates how these concepts can be applied to the 
marine sector, its products and services.

Name: Ecology 3
Description:
Marine communities, population dynamics of marine communities, descriptive
statistics, biodiversity

Name: Marine Biology 3
Description:
Introduction and the characteristics and faunal affinities of marine vertebrates: 
Fish: taxonomy, ecology, reproduction, ecophysiology and behaviour of agnathans, 
elasmobranchs and teleosts. 
Reptiles: taxonomy and characteristics, ecology, reproduction and ecophysiological 
adaptations. 
Birds: origin and structure, ecological adaptations, oceanic and flightless birds. 
Marine mammals: characteristics, ecophysiology and ecology, including behaviour 
of marine carnivores.

Name: Marine Science 3
Description:
Coordinate systems in fluid dynamics, Navier-Stokes equations of motion, 
inertial motions, geostrophic balance, Ekman-dynamics. Ocean temperature and 
salinity patterns, oxygen, carbon, nitrogen and micronutrient profiles and cycling.

Name: Coastal Management 3
Description:
Coastal Management 3 examines how integrated coastal management (ICM) 
improves marine protected areas (MPAs) management and administration applying 
relevant legislation, strategies, and policies. An introduction to MPA management 
planning and frameworks and the development of appropriate content for different 
types of MPAs. An introduction to the theory and methodology applied for the 
monitoring and evaluation of the effectiveness and performance for sustainable 
MPAs.

Name: Marine Aquaculture 2
Description:
Marine Aquaculture 2 introduces the various components of aquatic animal 
containment, including the design and function of marine aquaculture systems.It 
examines the importance of water quality maintenance to suit the species, 
including how to achieve optimal water quality, and the nutritional well-being of 
the species in culture. It presents the policies, legislation and management 
practices, including best practice, associated with marine aquaculture in South 
Africa.

Name: Marine Law 2
Description:
Marine Law 2 introduces various international agreements that relate to the 
governance of the marine and coastal environments as well as the international 
organisations that develop and administer these agreements. It also presents the 
domestic law regime and the framework for the development and administration of 
marine and coastal related legislation. It interrogates both the international and 
national legal regime as it relates to coastal climate change, environmental impact 
assessment, fisheries management, shipping and pollution and other related 
activities.

Name: Marine Science Industry Practice 1

Prerequisite.Comment: All theory subjects in the previous 5 semesters

Description:
Students are expected to work for 5 months in an appropriate workplace, i.e. 
marine protected area, marine company, research institution or laboratory. The 
techniques utilised at the workplace must be from any one of the following fields: 
marine aquaculture, marine conservation, marine environmental consultancies, 
oceanography or marine companies.

Name: Applications Development Fundamentals 2
Description:
Welcome to the 2nd year of Information and Communication Technology Diploma in Application 
Development. Application Development Fundamentals II is taught across all 3 specialization areas. 
With the increasing volume of electronic data in the modern digital world, it is particularly important to 
develop specialized ways to store and organize this data so that programs can access and operate on 
them more efficiently. The purpose of this subject is to learn and understand how to write efficient programs 
with respect to both time and space parameters using Java as the programming language. Conceptual 
organization of data is one of the most important considerations when developing software. In this subject 
you will learn about the usage of data structures and algorithms in computer programming. You are 
required to complete the practical exercises to reinforce your understanding of the concepts.

Name: Applications Development Practice 2
Description:
Welcome to the 2nd year of the Diploma in Information and Communication Technology in Applications Development.
Applications Development Practice II will guide students to create GUI based applications in Java, client-server applications and to create applications that interact with databases.
Students will participate in problem solving exercises to eventually understand and implement object-oriented programming concepts.

Name: Applications Development Theory 2
Description:
This subject introduces Systems Analysis & Design principles and concepts at a basic level. The theory of 
Systems Analysis & Design as well as practical applications will be covered, with the main emphasis on 
the analysis phase. Qualifying learners will produce assignments illustrating practical understanding of 
Systems Analysis & Design, demonstrate various analysis and documentation skills which will enable them 
to plan and design information systems creatively, professionally, and efficiently in accordance with 
international standards in this field. 
Although the emphasis during this year is to acquire, interpret and discuss new knowledge, the critical 
evaluation of facts, the practical application thereof and the solution of problem situations in practice 
will be encouraged through the use of a real-life business entity.

Name: Communications Networks Fundamentals 2
Description:
Welcome to Communication Network Fundamentals 2. This subject provides the foundation for 
understanding the key issues associated with protecting information assets, determining the 
levels of protection and response to security incidents, designing a consistent, reasonable 
information security system, with appropriate intrusion detection and reporting features. The 
purpose of the course is to provide the student with an overview of the field of information 
security and assurance. Students will be exposed to the spectrum of security activities, 
methods, methodologies, and procedures. Coverage will include inspection and protection of 
information assets, detection of and reaction to threats to information assets, and examination 
of pre- and post-incident procedures, technical and managerial responses, and an overview 
of the information.

Name: ICT Electives 2: An Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
Description:
Welcome to the 2nd year of the Diploma in Information and Communication Technology in Applications Development.
ICT Electives II – An Introduction to Artificial Intelligence is one of eleven Electives taught across all 3 specialisation areas. 
The purpose of this subject is to provide students with an introduction the theoretical concepts that underpin intelligent
behaviour in systems, and the design of AI systems. Students will learn the nature of machine intelligence and the various 
Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques that can be implemented in computer system in order to facilitate human intelligent behaviour in machines to a reasonable level.

Name: Information Management 2
Description:
Welcome to the 2nd year of the Diploma in Information and Communication Technology in Application 
Development. Information Management II is taught across all 3 specialisation areas. 
This subject exposes students to fundamental information management concepts and provides students 
with a sound basis for their subsequent levels of study and eventually their engagement in the world of 
work. 
Since most functional areas in business rely on information systems, an understanding of information 
management principles enables students to understand the concepts of strategy and strategic 
management of information in the IT and broader business context. The subject also exposes the student 
to the practicality of the concept of relational databases, through the introduction to basic functions of 
the structured language query for the design and management of databases. 
This course offers dynamic and engaging content to successfully teach students the issues relating to 
information management in their personal, professional and academic lives through exercises that focus 
on problem-solving and critical thinking and to place it into perspective with knowledge and experience 
acquired from lectures, independent research, reflection, tests, assignments and practical projects.

Name: Information Systems 2
Description:
Welcome to the 2nd year of the Diploma in Information and Communication Technology in Application 
Development. Information Systems II is the application development specialisation area. 
The purpose of this subject is to provide students with the fundamental knowledge of designing simple 
databases by means of entity relationship diagrams and the implementation of these designs in a relational 
database management system. Effective databases are essential tools in the contemporary business 
environment, and the ability to store, modify, extract and search for information through databases is a 
valuable skill in this environment. Leveraging project based learning techniques, students will create and 
work with problems which challenge them to design, implement, and demonstrate a database solution 
for a business or organization

Name: Multimedia Applications Fundamentals 2
Description:
Welcome to the 2nd year of the Diploma in Information and Communication Technology. Multimedia 
Application Fundamentals II is taught across all 3 specialisation areas. 
The purpose of this subject is to analyse and engage in critical thinking involving design in digital space. 
The design concepts presented in this subject are centred around principles that cover the vast knowledge 
base of UX (User experience and UI (User interface) design. Throughout the year, topics that range from 
general colour theory, accessibility and universal principles of design will be covered. The bulk of the 
subject is theory but seminar style discussions in in class practicals will also take place. The goal is for student 
to understand the concepts and design implementation of UX and UI principles and to be able to apply 
them regardless of academic stream specialisation.

Name: Professional Communications 2
Description:
Professional Communication 2 is a mandatory second year course in the Department of
Information Technology. It is designed to equip learners
with critical academic and professional skills which can enhance their
performance at the university and in the workplace.

Name: Project 2
Description:
This subject aims to give you an experience of working in a team on Information Technology (IT) projects, solving 
problems in Information and Communication Technology (ICT). This subject will require you to consolidate the 
application and integration of the techniques, skills, and concepts that you learnt over the years in various subjects. 
As an introduction to a formal project team working over an extended period, you will be assigned to a team and 
asked to provide an ICT solution to the problems that you will agree on with your supervisors. 
Core values of this subject is: 
• Understand how teams work on IT projects. 
• Work in a team with team members that has been created by the supervisor. 
• Understand how to document work. 
• Apply the knowledge you have gained in the course to solve problems. 
• Demonstrate the completed project.

Name: Marine Science I
Description: Introduction to scope and history of oceanography and seamanship

Name: Communication Skills I
Description:
To develop competencies in academic reading and writing, as well as develop 
presentation skills and interacting with visual aids when presenting. To develop 
research skills through exposure to information literacy and to evaluate relevance 
of information to assigned topics. To put into practice the understanding of 
avoiding plagiarism by in-text referencing and using a reference list.

Name: Biomathematics
Description:
Introduction of calculus to solve problems in Marine science context such as use of 
differentiation and integration to real-life applications in the study of radioactive 
decay, population growth and kinematics. Furthermore, the course enables 
students to apply their knowledge of probability and descriptive statistics to 
process data and make informed decisions in the face of uncertainty.

Name: Marine Chemistry I
Description:
Chemistry 1 aims to familiarize students with the fundamental principles of 
Chemistry by reinforcing and building on the principles of chemistry taught at 
secondary school level. It is a general subject, providing a platform for further study 
within the various disciplines of chemistry. The subject seeks to provide a basic 
understanding of theory and good laboratory practices.

Name: Marine Physics I
Description:
Marine Physics provides quantitative and analytic skills needed for analyzing data
and solving problems in the sciences. Physics helps us to understand how the world
around us works.

Name: Financial Accounting 1
Description:
The purpose of this subject is to develop the competency of students to understand and 
apply the fundamentals of accounting, based primarily on the principles of the Conceptual 
Framework for Financial Reporting and the IFRS. These principles are applied to service 
entities as well as trading entities, which include sole traders, partnerships and close 
corporations. The main intention of the subject is to equip students with the fundamental 
skills to record transactions and events appropriately, and to report them meaningfully and 
usefully.

Name: Business Law
Description:
The purpose of this subject is to provide students with a sound practical understanding of the 
fundamental principles of the Law of Obligations within the South African commercial context. 
The fundamental principles serve as the building blocks for the specific contracts. 
Students are expected to be able to read with comprehension and express themselves 
effectively through written and oral communication. The formative assessments also require 
students to be able to manage themselves and their studies responsibly. 
We trust that your experience in this subject will be worthwhile and wish you success with your 
studies.

Name: Statistics for Accountants 1
Description: The purpose of this course is to give the learner an appreciation of the role of Statistics in the area of Accountancy, with a strong emphasis placed on financial calculations. The two main objectives of this subject are to: 1. Equip students with the knowledge to perform basic mathematical and financial calculations  in the business environment as a means of assisting in decision-making, and to  2. Illustrate to students how to manipulate and present data meaningfully to support managerial  decision-making.

Name: Advanced Health Care Professional Practice 4
Description:
Advanced Health Care Professional Practice 4 (RT) is offered in the 4th year of study which focuses
on the application of Management Principles within the workplace. This subject will also have a
quality management focus, with consideration of equipment, human resources, quality assurance and health care
needs within the radiation oncology context. The purpose of the subject is to equip the students with the knowledge and
skills necessary to become effective radiation therapy managers applying these principles. The subject is mainly offered at the Bellville campus.

Name: Human Sciences 4
Description:
Human Sciences IV is concerned with the theory and radiobiology underpinning certain anatomical
systems of the human body demonstrated using specialised imaging.  The twin focus of this subject is therefore:
to review anatomy, physiology and pathology of the systems described below with a focus to understand the radiographic
appearances thereof on cross sectional imaging. Students are encouraged to do a thorough revision of previously
learnt anatomy, physiology and pathology. Furthermore, the integrated knowledge of the clinical application of 3-D anatomy in terms
of patient treatment plans and normal tissue side-effects.
To explain, apply and discuss radiobiological principles to radiation therapy practice. Topics such as:  oncogenesis,
normal tissue tolerance, critical organs at risk and radiation side-effects in clinical radiotherapy.

Name: Physics of Radiation Therapy 4
Description:
Overview: Physics of Radiation Therapy 4 (RT) is concerned with the theory underpinning the
knowledge of radiotherapy physics in order that the various radiation therapy modalities and
radiotherapy planning needed integrates the theoretical knowledge  with the practical applications in the
clinical work situation. The implementation of the theoretical knowledge combined with the clinical skills
is to provide  quality radiation therapy treatment in the clinical work situation and can be thus
integrated with the subject Radiation Therapy Practice 4 (RT). In fourth year, the focus of this subject is
on the operational principles and components of specialized imaging, planning software and radiation
treatment equipment coupled with the necessary quality assurance protocols.

Name: Health Science Research 4
Description:
The Subject Health Science Research 4 will be based on a strong foundational knowledge of concepts
and principles learnt in Health Sciences Research 3. It is therefore imperative that students have a solid
and integral understanding of Health Science Research processes and principles. The subject will further
revolve around an application of previously learnt knowledge in this subject area.
The teaching philosophy of this subject is underscored by a strong student centred focus. Diverse
student centred teaching methods and materials will be utilised to facilitate an effective, dynamic
teaching and learning environment to prepare BSc students for the Health Science Research in a
professional environment in order to inform policy, Professional Best Practice and Health outcomes. This
subject will foster independent and lifelong learning. Students are therefore encouraged to critically read
scholarly articles related to their discipline in order to develop analytical scientific skills.

Name: Health Science Research 4
Description:
The Subject Health Science Research 4 will be based on a strong foundational knowledge of concepts
and principles learnt in Health Sciences Research 3. It is therefore imperative that students have a solid
and integral understanding of Health Science Research processes and principles. The subject will further
revolve around an application of previously learnt knowledge in this subject area.
The teaching philosophy of this subject is underscored by a strong student centred focus. Diverse
student centred teaching methods and materials will be utilised to facilitate an effective, dynamic
teaching and learning environment to prepare BSc students for the Health Science Research in a
professional environment in order to inform policy, Professional Best Practice and Health outcomes. This
subject will foster independent and lifelong learning. Students are therefore encouraged to critically read
scholarly articles related to their discipline in order to develop analytical scientific skills.

Name: Radiation Therapy Practice 4
Description:
Radiation Therapy Practice is concerned with the theory underpinning the various
conventional and specialised oncology treatment techniques.  In the fourth year the clinical focus is on
the application of the theory applied to the advanced treatment and planning protocols of all systems in
the clinical workplace. Revision of the conventional 2-D and 3-D techniques underpin the discussion of
applied theory

Name: Entrepreneurship 4

Prerequisite.Comment:
(Radiographic) Management 3 which would include knowledge of Management
Principles, Professionalism, Communication and Ethics (business and medical).

Description:
The electives are offered in the 4th level of the BSc programme. A topic that interests the student is
normally chosen as an elective.  It is credit bearing (20 of 40 credits) and when added to the
compulsory subjects, it should add up to the total number of credits needed to complete the BSc
degree. 

The aim of this elective is to provide students with opportunities to:
• to acquire knowledge and develop skills necessary to plan and begin a business
• to understand the role that entrepreneurs play in the country, society and economy.

Name: Entrepreneurship 4

Prerequisite.Comment:
(Radiographic) Management 3 which would include knowledge of Management
Principles, Professionalism, Communication and Ethics (business and medical).

Description:
The electives are offered in the 4th level of the BSc programme. A topic that interests the student is
normally chosen as an elective.  It is credit bearing (20 of 40 credits) and when added to the
compulsory subjects, it should add up to the total number of credits needed to complete the BSc
degree. 

The aim of this elective is to provide students with opportunities to:
• to acquire knowledge and develop skills necessary to plan and begin a business
• to understand the role that entrepreneurs play in the country, society and economy.

Name: Health Science Education: Common Elective
Description:
Learners choosing this elective will be exposed to teaching and learning theories, practices and
assessment methods used in health science education. The scope of this elective is to equip learners with
the theoretical knowledge needed to understand the complexities of educational theories, clinical
teaching practices and assessment in the 21st century. 
After completing this elective, learners will be able to start a career path in education (for example, clinical
mentor, clinical instructor, lecturer, etc.)

Name: Health Science Education: Common Elective
Description:
Learners choosing this elective will be exposed to teaching and learning theories, practices and
assessment methods used in health science education. The scope of this elective is to equip learners with
the theoretical knowledge needed to understand the complexities of educational theories, clinical
teaching practices and assessment in the 21st century. 
After completing this elective, learners will be able to start a career path in education (for example, clinical
mentor, clinical instructor, lecturer, etc.)

Name: Advanced Radiotherapy Dosimetry and Graphic Planning 4
Description:
This elective course is specifically designed for radiation therapists to become more specialized in
radiation therapy planning and dosimetry. The elective will require you to apply specialized academic
knowledge and technical skills that are applicable to various therapeutic techniques of optimal radiation
treatment in this chosen elective which in this case includes graphic and localization planning
methodology.
